text: here was running off we're turning off
the main road onto a back road it is
technically illegal for Israelis to
travel in these parts of the West Bank
but this group doesn't seem to mind by
taking these bumpy dirt roads they are
able to bypass military checkpoints and
reach their destination a settlement
that is not supposed to exist anymore
rabbi Alicia mccowen embarks on this
journey nearly every day the rabbi is
part of a group officially known as
himesh first which aims to resettle all
of the former settlements that had been
evacuated by Israel in the West Bank and
Gaza starting with the safest and most
accessible one a settlement called pho
mesh we have returned to the Land of
Israel after being banished for 2,000
years and we do not intend on being
vanished again from our land the
government might through negotiations
think that they can destroy a community
and force people out but any opportunity
that we have we will return reporting by
the new york times over several months
across the west bank has indicated that
settlers are unlikely to resort to
organized violence to prevent further
withdrawals but that they will engage in
acts of civil disobedience to prove
their point this was himesh four years
ago it was founded in nineteen eighty in
the northern West Bank up until August
of 2005 60 families lived here under the
protection of the Israeli army
that year the army evacuated himesh
along with three other West Bank
settlements as part of Israel's
disengagement plan the more
ideologically driven Jewish settlers
resisted the government's orders and
were forcibly removed from their homes
and synagogues while much of the world's
attention was focused on the large-scale
pullout from Gaza this was intended to
be the first step in a more
comprehensive West Bank withdrawal
unlike the Gaza Strip settlements which
were handed over to the Palestinian
Authority and later controlled by Hamas
the four west bank settlements were
retained by the Israeli army himesh at
least in theory was to become a closed
military zone the infrastructure of the
settlement still exists the only thing
missing here are the residents the Jews
this was the settlement synagogue those
are the head offices the dormitories of
the achieva over there been Eagle used
to live in the settlement and often
comes back to visit Benny walks around
to inspect the still functioning water
system and takes a stroll around his old
block it was a human tragedy what
happened four years ago we miss it here
the grass nearly covers the lot where
his house once stood it was here four
years ago that he was dragged from his
home against his will if someone asked
me where i live i tell them himesh if
you asked my son where he's from he'll
say home-ish sure today I live in
another place but I'm from himesh on
Mondays and Thursdays the rabbi brings a
Torah to where the settlements synagogue
once stood 15 students take turns
reading from their holy book and spent
much of the day studying and praying no
10 hat
the group has maintained a constant
presence in himesh for the past two
years both the Israeli government and
army know full well that they're here
but they have chosen thus far to ignore
them a Deputy Prime Minister recently
visited the settlement against the
wishes of Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu exposing divisions in the
government's inner circle I thought
vomited said William deneva me team came
out immediately to me if you deem
history says the great and true things
always start with individuals we are the
first screen shoots in a great
revolution that must happen in the
nation of Israel rabbi Cohen sees his
group as the stewards of a Jewish
revolution of sorts I mean I believe
with complete faith in the coming of the
Messiah the revolution that Rob I Cohen
refers to is the coming of the Messiah
which he believes is connected to Jews
settling himesh and the rest of Greater
Israel who to them a lot it's Nevada
this others both are right to this land
stems from the fact that God gave it to
us and as long as it is not in our hands
the whole world will face calamities
once the Jews recognize our rights to
this land and stand up for what is ours
that will bring a solution to all the
world's problems
today is a special day in home ish the
students completed an entire track date
of the talmud they dance the hora and
sing in celebration it is considered
unsafe to leave the Torah here overnight
so before dusk it is zipped back up and
taken to a neighboring settlement a core
group of settlers will remain for their
nightly guard duty unsure of what
tomorrow will bring for the New York
Times this is ethan bronner in himesh
the west bank
